name: Chain
comment:
A chain of stack traces.

A stack chain is a collection of one or more stack traces that collectively represent the path from main through nested function calls to a particular code location, usually where an error was thrown. Multiple stack traces are necessary when using asynchronous functions, since the program's stack is reset before each asynchronous callback is run.

Stack chains can be automatically tracked using stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture. This sets up a new stack_trace/dart-async.Zone in which the current stack chain is tracked and can be accessed using new Chain.current. Any errors that would be top-leveled in the zone can be handled, along with their associated chains, with the onError callback. For example:

Chain.capture(() {
  // ...
}, onError: (error, stackChain) {
  print("Caught error $error\n"
        "$stackChain");
});

For the most part stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture will notice when an error is thrown and associate the correct stack chain with it; the chain can be accessed using new Chain.forTrace. However, there are some cases where exceptions won't be automatically detected: any stack_trace/dart-async.Future constructor, stack_trace/dart-async.Completer.completeError, Stream.addError, and libraries that use these. For these, all you need to do is wrap the Future or Stream in a call to stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track and the errors will be tracked correctly.

traces.name: traces
traces.comment:
The stack traces that make up this chain.

Like the frames in a stack trace, the traces are ordered from most local to least local. The first one is the trace where the actual exception was raised, the second one is where that callback was scheduled, and so on.

terse.name: terse
terse.comment:
Returns a terser version of this.

This calls stack_trace/trace.Trace.terse on every trace in stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.traces, and discards any trace that contain only internal frames.

current.name: current
current.comment:
Returns the current stack chain.

By default, the first frame of the first trace will be the line where stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-current is called. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-current.level is passed, the first trace will start that many frames up instead.

If this is called outside of a stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture zone, it just returns a single-trace chain.

forTrace.name: forTrace
forTrace.comment:
Returns the stack chain associated with stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-forTrace.trace.

The first stack trace in the returned chain will always be stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-forTrace.trace (converted to a stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace if necessary). If there is no chain associated with stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-forTrace.trace or if this is called outside of a stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture zone, this just returns a single-trace chain containing stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-forTrace.trace.

If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.Chain-forTrace.trace is already a stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain, it will be returned as-is.

parse.name: parse
parse.comment:
Parses a string representation of a stack chain.

Specifically, this parses the output of stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.toString.

capture.name: capture
capture.comment:
Runs stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.callback in a stack_trace/dart-async.Zone in which the current stack chain is tracked and automatically associated with (most) errors.

If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.onError is passed, any error in the zone that would otherwise go unhandled is passed to it, along with the stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain associated with that error. Note that if stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.callback produces multiple unhandled errors, stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.onError may be called more than once. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.onError isn't passed, the parent Zone's unhandledErrorHandler will be called with the error and its chain.

For the most part an error thrown in the zone will have the correct stack chain associated with it. However, there are some cases where exceptions won't be automatically detected: any stack_trace/dart-async.Future constructor, stack_trace/dart-async.Completer.completeError, Stream.addError, and libraries that use these. For these, all you need to do is wrap the Future or Stream in a call to stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track and the errors will be tracked correctly.

Note that even if stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.onError isn't passed, this zone will still be an error zone. This means that any errors that would cross the zone boundary are considered unhandled.

If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture.callback returns a value, it will be returned by stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture as well.

Currently, capturing stack chains doesn't work when using dart2js due to issues 15171 and 15105. Stack chains reported on dart2js will contain only one trace.

track.name: track
track.comment:
Ensures that any errors emitted by stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track.futureOrStream have the correct stack chain information associated with them.

For the most part an error thrown within a stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture zone will have the correct stack chain automatically associated with it. However, there are some cases where exceptions won't be automatically detected: any stack_trace/dart-async.Future constructor, stack_trace/dart-async.Completer.completeError, Stream.addError, and libraries that use these.

This returns a stack_trace/dart-async.Future or stack_trace/dart-async.Stream that will emit the same values and errors as stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track.futureOrStream. The only exception is that if stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track.futureOrStream emits an error without a stack trace, one will be added in the return value.

If this is called outside of a stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.capture zone, it just returns stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track.futureOrStream as-is.

As the name suggests, stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.track.futureOrStream may be either a stack_trace/dart-async.Future or a stack_trace/dart-async.Stream.

foldFrames.name: foldFrames
foldFrames.comment:
Returns a new stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain based on this where multiple stack frames matching stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.foldFrames.predicate are folded together.

This means that whenever there are multiple frames in a row that match stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.foldFrames.predicate, only the last one is kept. In addition, traces that are composed entirely of frames matching stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.foldFrames.predicate are omitted.

This is useful for limiting the amount of library code that appears in a stack trace by only showing user code and code that's called by user code.

toTrace.name: toTrace
toTrace.comment:
Converts this to a stack_trace/stack_trace.Trace.

The trace version of a chain is just the concatenation of all the traces in the chain.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment:
Returns a dart-core.String representation of the stack trace.

The string represents the full stack trace starting from the point where a throw ocurred to the top of the current call sequence.

The exact format of the string representation is not final.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment:
Returns a dart-core.String representation of the stack trace.

The string represents the full stack trace starting from the point where a throw ocurred to the top of the current call sequence.

The exact format of the string representation is not final.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of stack_trace/stack_trace.Chain.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
